{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3692692,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T13:55:52.378Z","cooked":"

Our team has always run a daisy-chained CAN bus, and with that comes the risk of a single failure taking down our entire robot. I’ve been exploring ways to improve our CAN setup, and so far, we’ve decided to use two CANivores to separate our drivetrain and superstructure CAN, allowing us to keep our drivetrain functional and play defense in the event of a failure.

I was thinking about how we could implement even more redundancy, and it dawned on me that Star topology might be the answer. My idea was to have the 2 separate CANivore buses, keeping the drivetrain daisy-chained while adding a hub to the superstructure bus to implement Star topology.

I know there are many merits to Star topology, but I also know that there are risks that come with improperly setting it up. That’s why I wanted to get any advice on how it works for your team, if it’s even worth setting up, tips on how to make a proper Star bus, any other topologies you’d recommend, and even reasons not to use it.

I greatly appreciate any advice and information you can give. Thanks in advance.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T13:55:52.378Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":419,"readers_count":418,"score":212.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692698,"name":"Drew Williams","username":"jreneew2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jreneew2/{size}/135239_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T14:11:31.855Z","cooked":"

If you are using a canivore dont use anything but daisy chain. It can hurt the reliability of the bus or just not work properly.

To improve the reliability of your CAN networks, use

  • use pre twisted CAN wire
  • molex SL or solder with good technique
  • use jacketed wire where it might get cut by something
  • don’t stub > 12 in.,
  • strain relief
  • systems checks before each match.

Thats really all there is too it. Basically, whatever you do, do it to the best of your ability and don’t be lazy with it. You will have a bulletproof CAN network.

Here are some relevant threads:

CAN Connection Preferences Technical
Over the weekend I saw many many many faikures of CAN connections, fortunately these have gotten significantly easier to debug (thanks REV and CTRE <3) and find the bad connection quickly. However the question i kept asking myself was “How should you connect CAN lines reliably while still able to fix them when an issue occurs”. While I like WAGO’s there were several occasions where they were the source of the problem too. Another thing to note is slack, a properly wired CAN bus has some slack…
What Are the Best Practices for a Reliable CAN Bus Setup? Electrical
Hi everyone, Our team has been facing ongoing issues with the reliability of our CAN bus network. In the past, we used 2-pin connectors, but they proved to be quite unreliable. As a temporary solution, we started soldering the wires directly, but we’ve found this makes maintenance and repairs very difficult and time-consuming. Now, we’re planning to rebuild our CAN bus system from scratch using clean and properly routed wires. Before we do, I wanted to ask: what setups have worked well for you…
Star Can Wiring Electrical
Hi CD, Our team is looking to improve our can wiring this offseason. We plan to switch from daisy chaining to a star can wiring system, where each device has its own can wire route, and a break in the loop does not spell disaster for the entire robot that match. Are there any good terminals that we should use to split the wire into a terminal for multiple connections (if this makes any sense; like where the central can wire splits off to connect to each device in the can network)? Thanks
Can Bus wiring connectors CAN
What is the “best” way to connect devices to the Can Bus? We’ll be using Spark Controllers mostly. Thanks, -Brian

Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T14:26:55.920Z","cooked":"

I’ve used “star” topology (technically “bus” the way we use it) on our low-speed network for the better part of the last 10 years and it’s been basically flawless, especially as we’ve improved our connection methods over time.

With our teams move towards the CTRE ecosystem, we’ve found ourselves using CAN FD to a limited degree on our robot. This is more of a programming requirement, since depending on how you utilize the CTRE control functionality, it can be a pretty heavy load on the standard CAN 2.0 network. In general, you can’t really use Star/Bus Topology on the CAN FD network (we got it working to a limited degree with <10 devices on a short run one time, but it was temperamental to say the least.

For the last few years our standard procedure is to wire the drivetrain motors/sensors and any other static CTRE components on the chassis using the CANivore/CAN FD network in daisy chain; since these devices are in the most protected spots, the risk of accidental disconnects taking down the drivetrain is generally low. For everything else (Non-CTRE, above the chassis, moving components, etc.), we run on the RIO/CAN 2.0 on Star/Bus using some simple custom distribution hubs we’ve developed over the years…

kdp7UdZ1250×552 56.7 KB

To my knowledge, using this setup we have had zero CAN issues during matches in the last 2 years (we had one repeat issue in 2023 with a CANCoder that refused to stay soldered, but that was about it).

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T14:26:55.920Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":339,"readers_count":338,"score":146.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692706,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T14:28:03.263Z","cooked":"

That’s what I had thought. I had gotten somewhat confused because I had heard of Star topology on a CANivore being done before. If we end up not using a CANivore for a superstructure bus, then we might still consider star, otherwise, we’ll stick to daisy-chaining. Thanks for the threads, I’ll definitely be taking a look at those.

This seems like what I was thinking. I found a hub on Playing With Fusion similar to your custom one. Are all the devices you run on the Star bus strictly non-CTRE devices like NEOs? We run a full CTRE ecosystem with Krakens, so I doubt this would work for us.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T14:35:53.946Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":290,"readers_count":289,"score":62.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":6560,"username":"cbale2000","name":"Chris Bale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692718,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T14:47:03.278Z","cooked":"

No, this past year we ran all CTRE as well but still used this configuration. Star offers a lot of redundancy (since a single failure won’t take down the whole network, generally), especially when moving parts are involved. The drivetrain is also the biggest drain on CAN network utilization, so once you separate that out, you can pretty much run everything else on CAN 2.0 with no issues.

In general, my preference would be to run everything on Star, if it weren’t for the limited bandwidth of the 2.0 network. Running both is more of a compromise solution than anything, but it’s good enough if you’re smart about it. A team without a high CAN bus utilization on 2.0 could probably use Star for the whole robot with no issues, we are just not one of those teams.

The Playing with Fusion boards are pretty similar to ours, so you’d probably be fine going that way. Swyft also has an interesting solution for Daisy Chain CAN and power, though I don’t know how much I trust RJ45 connectors.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T14:54:25.031Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":84.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://swyftrobotics.com/products/swyft-cannect-wiring-system","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SWYFT CANnect Wiring System – SWYFT Robotics","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65551,"username":"elctrilica","name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692725,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T15:02:00.901Z","cooked":"

Our programming team said that more than 4 Krakens on the 2.0 network would be hard to manage, but I’ll talk to them about it in more detail. We’re sticking with daisy chaining our swerve drive separately, so it shouldn’t be a problem with what you’re saying.

The Swyft solution is pretty interesting and something I considered, but I wasn’t completely on board with it.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T15:02:00.901Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":249,"readers_count":248,"score":54.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":6560,"username":"cbale2000","name":"Chris Bale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692728,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T15:04:52.532Z","cooked":"

We had ~7 Krakens plus 3-4 sensors running on our 2.0 network this year with no utilization issues whatsoever. The reason separating the drive motors on a swerve from the 2.0 network helps so much is how the CTRE environment communicates between swerve motors and sensors, but individual motors running their own PIDs and functions don’t cause as much of a draw on the network (at least that’s how I understand it, not a programmer).

If you’re having issues running more than 4x standalone Krakens on the 2.0 network, I would suggest reaching out to CTRE’s support (they’re very helpful), as you might be doing something wrong.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T15:08:52.064Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":107.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65551,"username":"elctrilica","name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692738,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T15:19:13.549Z","cooked":"

This is the wiring topology of a typical CANbus

image499×185 8.78 KB

A CTRE-style daisy chain is still that same CANbus topology, but with each node having a connector placed along its segment of wire, creating potential breakpoints along the trunk of the bus. Each of these blue dots represents the connections between devices being daisy chained together.

image499×185 20.7 KB

The risk of having all those termination points along the bus is obvious, and it’s understandable to want to move away from that layout. My preferred suggestion is 22AWG wire taps.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T15:19:13.549Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":107.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692812,"name":"Harrison","username":"hjmcphail76","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hjmcphail76/{size}/234713_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T16:56:59.545Z","cooked":"

STAR Topology has worked flawless for us this year. We used a combined shielded high/low signal wire so it was robust and each swerve module and other subsystem got it’s own CAN run. Not a single failure or outage the whole season, compared to seemingly every other match the year before (we took the upgrade seriously.) Highly recommend. All our connections to the device plug in to green/yellow cables were done with combined crimp/heat shrink connectors.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T16:58:42.312Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":73.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Harrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692895,"name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","username":"elctrilica","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T17:56:49.159Z","cooked":"

The information here is great, and I’ve been learning a lot, so thanks to everyone. One question I have is about stub length. I know that they’re supposed to stay under 12", but this seems impossible to me since I feel like motors and other devices are inevitably going to be further than 12" from the hub. How do you get around this?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T18:33:25.168Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Mithul Balasubramanian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":23042,"username":"BrianAtlanta","name":"BrianAtlanta","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brianatlanta/{size}/7578_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"862 Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/13","reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692952,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T19:14:20.943Z","cooked":"

Keep in mind that there’s more choices than just “daisy chain” and “star topology.” You can route the “trunk” of your bus (the main CAN_H & CAN_L wires) in a reasonable path that keeps your stubs <12" and then use other connectors (such as wire taps) to split the stubs off the trunk.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T19:14:20.943Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":51.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65551,"username":"elctrilica","name":"Mithul Balasubramanian","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elctrilica/{size}/264271_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/14","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692961,"name":"JBENJI","username":"JBENJI","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c6cbf5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T19:32:21.265Z","cooked":"

This is probably crazy, expensive, and certainly not scientifically based - but while we use a daisy chain layout, last year we ended up using 2 CANivores in order to separate out segments of our robot. And yeah, that added (maybe) another potential failure point with the USB connections to the roborio.

Better advice - we pretty much exclusively use Krakens and CANcoders and build our own CAN segments between devices - cut to length and crimped in house so we have next to zero solder connections (except on the CANcoders and terminating resistors) and zero other connections such as molex.
We also use the jacketed wire where things are potentially prone to being cut, but we all generally hate trying to cut thru that jacket without nicking the green/yellow wires…

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T19:33:55.104Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":51.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"JBENJI","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28067,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/15","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692963,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T19:34:03.061Z","cooked":"

There some people here making claims “our star works great” without supporting that with what bus they are running. That is critical. CTRE’s can implementation doesn’t require daisy chain although it’s strongly recommended. It is far more sensitive to star “abuse” than the rio’s native and slower can.

We used the canivore, and used a hybrid topology. This is what it looked like:

20250729_1517491920×796 75.4 KB

The small squares are what I’ll call a “hub”. It’s where we broke out the star from the trunk line.

We DID have problems with the can bus on initial setup. We kept stub lengths as short as possible. What we found, however, was that when we had two stubs close together, say the intake and a swerve module, and the “linear” distance if you measured back to the canivore along the wires overlapped, we would have problems. This was not surprising. As a result, when we had an issue like that, we would extend the wires between the hubs.

This is a picture of what I mean:

20250729_1517541920×1415 116 KB

On the right in the above diagram, the Intake “star” is long enough that it’s length back to the canivore overlaps with a device on the swerve “star”. The fix to this was to extend the cable between the intake and swerve so the devices are a significantly different ‘wire’ distance from the canivore as those on another star.

Following that worked. However…

Take this all with a giant grain of salt. It took us a couple tries to get the lengths correct as we worked through the bus. And I was worried about the ‘what if it fails’ all season. At one point, we made a minor change to one of the stars during practice and it took the bus down until we lengthened another cable. It can be tricky, and you can spend a lot of time diagnosing a problem that you really shouldn’t be wasting time on.

Daisy chaining is the simple, reliable answer to the question “how should I run my can bus wiring?”. Just ask yourself “Do I want to be programming the robot, or troubleshooting my can bus?”

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T19:40:46.922Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":186,"readers_count":185,"score":151.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/16","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3692987,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-29T20:00:29.571Z","cooked":"

It likely that the root cause of many of the CAN problems being reported are due to bad/unreliable connections rather than the topology used. Either topology, poorly implemented will perform poorly.

By focusing your energies on improving the procedures used when making electrical connections will improve the overall reliability of your whole control system and your robot.

Ensure that your team members do a tug-test on each individual wire (not wire pair) immediately after making the connection.

Ensure that connectors cannot come apart. Use a small zip-tie to secure the black “PWM” connectors supplied with SparkMax’s.

Ensure that wires are strain relieved on both sides of a set of connectors to prevent tension from being applied to the connections when the wires move.

Ensure that there is never any tension on wires, especially at connection points. It is best to include a “service loop” consisting of an extra 1/2" to 1" of wire at each connection point. This allows movement in the wires without transferring force into the connection points. It also allows easier servicing of the connections.

The practices I described are commonly used in industry.

Yah this is my test setup on bench. I am using a star network with wago connector for ease of connection. Don’t ever try this on a real robot. It’s completely not up to standard but work completely fine. All my wire are less than two inch.

Again, this is not practical on most robot. I need this for testing.

2102 Build Thread 2024-25 Open Alliance FRC Open Alliance
Time for the first of hopefully a few writeups on sucessful practices we implemented this year that we will do before the season starts. Wiring Writeup We have had wiring issues for a long time, but this year we had one of our alumni come back to become a mentor. He does motorsports electronics, and helped us improve our wiring for this season. Information in this post comes from him via this writeup from @Footie. In addition, thanks to @Baby_Carrot and @Big_Ideas for additional info and clari…

My team has been using trunk-and-branch can topology for the past two years (see above writeup) and it has worked very well for us.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":43,"updated_at":"2025-07-29T21:22:00.788Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":65.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504771,"topic_slug":"what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining","display_username":"Paul Regnier","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/2102-build-thread-2024-25-open-alliance/476375/3","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"2102 Build Thread 2024-25 Open Alliance","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61214,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2102 Lead Programmer and OA Lead"},"post_url":"/t/what-are-your-experiences-with-can-topologies-other-than-daisy-chaining/504771/19","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3693213,"name":"Zach Hoegberg","username":"Zaque","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zaque/{size}/257827_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-30T00:25:25.396Z","cooked":"
philso:

It likely that the root cause of many of the CAN problems being reported are due to bad/unreliable connections rather than the topology used.

I don’t think the data exists to confidently make this claim, and if anything minimizes the very real issues with using a star topology with a high-speed CAN FD bus. Obviously, poor wiring standards will cause issues no matter what topology you use, but even with perfect wiring a star topology can still have issues with ringing, reflections, etc. that a standards-compliant daisy chain topology will not have.

Tom_Line:

Daisy chaining is the simple, reliable answer to the question “how should I run my can bus wiring?”. Just ask yourself “Do I want to be programming the robot, or troubleshooting my can bus?”

This is what it comes down to for me. Even with the roboRIO native CAN2.0 bus, I’d rather take the extra time and effort to make a daisy-chain bus and take extra precautions to protect the wiring than take the risk that a device change or rewiring or hot-swap will take down the whole bus and leave hours of troubleshooting to figure out.
